article.description:
Jordan Farmar turned in a mostly steady performance at point guard and
fellow freshman Arron Afflalo played solid defense in UCLA's
season-opening 64-53 victory over Chicago State on Saturday.
article.headline: Farmar, Afflalo star in first game
article.linkText: Fresh faces star in UCLA's opening victory
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- UCLA freshman Jordan Farmar gave fans a preview of his playmaking skills with a no-look, crosscourt pass to Ryan Hollins for a dunk late in the second half. Farmar turned in a mostly steady performance at point guard and fellow freshman Arron Afflalo played solid defense in UCLA's season-opening 64-53 victory over Chicago State on Saturday. Farmar and Afflalo started at the guard positions for UCLA, the third pair of newcomers to do so since 1980. "I wasn't too nervous," Farmar said. The flashy play that Farmar and Hollins teamed on wasn't in coach Ben Howland's plans. "I was getting pressured and I tried to beat the pressure," Farmar said. "I saw him downcourt, wide open and gave him the ball. He did the rest." But don't expect the Bruins to freelance on offense the way they did under former coach Steve Lavin. Howland preaches defense, and Farmar knows it. "That's all he ever talks to me about," he said. "I'm going to hear it all year." Dijon Thompson led four UCLA players in double figures with 17 points. The Bruins, who ended last season with six straight losses and an 11-17 record, didn't build a double-digit lead until about 14 minutes were left in the game. UCLA is 2-0 in openers under second-year coach Howland. A year ago, Hollins made a free throw in the final seconds to help the Bruins hang on to beat Vermont 68-67. Tony Weeden led Chicago State with 17 points. Royce Parran added 17. "I was proud of the way our team played and competed at UCLA in this environment, in this atmosphere," coach Kevin Jones said, referring to the 11 NCAA championship banners hanging around the court. Chicago State led by three points late in the first half before Thompson scored nine straight to give UCLA a 31-25 halftime lead. The Cougars closed to 36-33 early in the second half, helped by six straight points from Weeden and a layin by Marin Mulic. But the Bruins answered with a 10-0 run, including 3-pointers by Afflalo and Farmar, to go up 46-33 with 13:44 remaining. The Bruins led by 15 points when they went six minutes without a field goal, but Chicago State got no closer than seven points in that span. Farmar had 11 points, five assists and eight turnovers in 34 minutes running the offense in place of senior Cedric Bozeman, who tore a knee ligament and will miss the entire season. "All of his turnovers were in the half-court," Howland said. "He didn't have any turnovers forced by the press in the backcourt. A couple of them were like trying to throw the ball long to Arron when he's not open." Afflalo played solid defense, holding Parran to two points in the second half, and had five points in 34 minutes. "You won't see Arron Afflalo miss those kind of easy layups that he missed probably ever again the rest of the year," Howland said. "We're throwing him right in the fire. He is a very, very good player, as is Jordan." Michael Fey and Hollins, both 7-footers, also started together, along with Thompson. Hollins added 11 points. Fey had six points and missed two dunks that had the crowd of 6,833 groaning. The Cougars were outrebounded 41-21. "The big difference was the inside play," Jones said. "We got nothing out of our 7-1 center (Deji Akindele). But I thought our team earned some respect and showed we can play basketball, too." Chicago State fell to 3-17 in season openers. They were without Craig Franklin, last season's leading scorer who won't play until mid-December because of academic problems. Chicago State, 12-20 last season, is 0-5 against Pac-10 schools since joining Division I in 1984. UCLA freshman Lorenzo Mata missed the game after spraining his left ankle in practice Friday. X-rays were negative and he likely will miss Tuesday's game against Western Illinois.
